Question_1.Context: Chamomile is an annual herb that is sensitive to abiotic stress, which can affect the quality of its essential oil.
Question_1.Question: What is the impact of abiotic stress on chamomile?
Question_1.A: It has no significant impact on chamomile.
Question_1.B: It can improve the quality of chamomile's essential oil.
Question_1.C: It can easily affect the quality of chamomile's essential oil.
Question_1.D: It primarily affects the height of the chamomile plant.
Question_1.Source: Chamomile is sensitive to abiotic stress, such as heavy metals, heat damage, cold damage, and natural poisons. These factors can easily affect the quality of its essential oil.

Question_2.Context: Nicotine released into the soil during tobacco cultivation can affect subsequent crops by altering their physiological and metabolic responses.
Question_2.Question: How does nicotine in the soil influence subsequent crops?
Question_2.A: It enhances the flavor of the crops.
Question_2.B: It has no effect on the crops.
Question_2.C: It can alter the physiological and metabolic responses of the crops.
Question_2.D: It increases the size of the crops.
Question_2.Source: The nicotine released into the soil during tobacco cultivation has an impact on various aspects of chamomile growth, including plant height, flowering period, flower yield, and flower quality.

Question_3.Context: Antioxidant enzymes in plants, such as superoxide dismutase (SOD), peroxidase (POD), and catalase (CAT), play a role in protecting plants under stress conditions.
Question_3.Question: Which antioxidant enzymes are involved in protecting plants under stress conditions?
Question_3.Source: The measurement of indicators of the antioxidant enzyme system includes evaluating the levels of superoxide dismutase (SOD), peroxidase (POD), catalase (CAT).

Question_4.Context: Malondialdehyde (MDA) is a product of lipid peroxidation in plant cells and serves as an indicator of stress in plants.
Question_4.Question: What does an elevated level of malondialdehyde (MDA) in plants indicate?
Question_4.Source: In this study, elevated levels of MDA, the product of membrane lipid peroxidation, were observed in both N-100 and N-500 treatments.

Question_5.Context: Flavonoids, phenolic acids, organic acids, and other substances in chamomile flowers are associated with the plant's response to nicotine stress.
Question_5.Question: Which compounds in chamomile flowers are associated with the plant's response to nicotine stress?
Question_5.Source: The response of chamomile flowers to nicotine stress is associated with the presence of flavonoids, phenolic acids, organic acids, and other substances.

Question_6.Context: Metabolic regulation under nicotine stress in chamomile involves various processes, including aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis and glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism.
Question_6.Question: Which metabolic processes are involved in the regulation under nicotine stress in chamomile?
Question_6.B: Aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis and glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism
Question_6.C: Lipid synthesis and fatty acid elongation
Question_6.Source: Metabolic regulation under nicotine stress primarily involves processes, such as aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis, glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism.

Question_7.Context: The ABC (ATP-binding cassette) transporter activity in chamomile is one of the processes affected by nicotine stress.
Question_7.Question: What role does the ABC (ATP-binding cassette) transporter activity play in chamomile under nicotine stress?
Question_7.A: It is involved in pigment synthesis.
Question_7.B: It is unrelated to nicotine stress.
Question_7.C: It is involved in the transport of water across membranes.
Question_7.D: It is one of the processes affected by nicotine stress.
Question_7.Source: Metabolic regulation under nicotine stress primarily involves processes, such as ABC (ATP-binding cassette) transporter activity.

Question_8.Context: Pyrimidine metabolism is one of the metabolic pathways involved in the response of chamomile to nicotine stress.
Question_8.Question: Which metabolic pathway is involved in the response of chamomile to nicotine stress?
Question_8.Source: Metabolic regulation under nicotine stress primarily involves processes, such as pyrimidine metabolism.

Question_9.Context: Nicotine can be transported from the roots to other organs in chamomile during its growth period.
Question_9.Question: How is nicotine transported within chamomile plants?
Question_9.A: It remains only in the roots and is not transported.
Question_9.B: It is transported from the roots to other organs.
Question_9.C: It is synthesized in the leaves and moves to the roots.
Question_9.D: It is evenly distributed throughout the plant without transport.
Question_9.Source: It was observed that nicotine was transported from the roots to other organs during the entire growth period of chamomile.

Question_10.Context: Ultra-high-performance liquid chromatography-coupled tandem mass spectrometry (UHPLC–MS/MS) is a technique used to detect a wide range of metabolites in plant tissues.
Question_10.Question: What is the role of UHPLC–MS/MS in the study of plant metabolites?
Question_10.A: It is used to measure the pH level of plant tissues.
Question_10.B: It is used to detect the presence of water in plant tissues.
Question_10.C: It is used to detect a wide range of metabolites in plant tissues.
Question_10.D: It is used to determine the age of plant tissues.
Question_10.Source: A total of 1096 metabolites were detected by ultra-high-performance liquid chromatography-coupled tandem mass spectrometry (UHPLC–MS/MS) analysis.
